GEO113.name: Introduction to Economic Geography
GEO113.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GEO113.description: Spatial distribution of resources, population, enterprise, trade, consumption, and production. Interaction of those distributions at local to global scales.

GEO151.name: Introduction to Human Geography
GEO151.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GEO151.description: Systematic study of spatial patterns and processes that have shaped human use and alteration of the world.

GEO201.name: Introduction to Plant Geography
GEO201.description: Geographic distribution and characteristics of plants throughout the world; relationships between biomes and aspects of the physical environment (climate, soils, landforms, disturbance); plant ecology; human impacts on vegetation; optional field trip on campus.

GEO203.name: Introduction to Meteorology
GEO203.description: Fundamentals of meteorology. Energy balance, adiabatic processes, horizontal motion, cyclogenesis, and severe weather.

GEO204.name: World Regional Geography
GEO204.description: Economic, political, cultural, environmental, and technological processes and conditions that explain the diversity of world regions.

GEO206.name: Physical Geography
GEO206.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GEO206.description: Geographic and functional interrelationships within the physical environment

GEO206L.name: Physical Geography Laboratory
GEO206L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GEO206L.description: Geographic aspects of weather, climate, soil, vegetation, and terrain. Interpretation and application of maps and remotely sensed imagery.
GEO206L.prerequisite: GEO 113 or GEO 151 or GEO 203 or GEO 204 or (GEO 206 or concurrently) or GEO 208 or GEO 211 or GEO 215 or GEO 221

GEO208.name: Physical Geography of the National Parks
GEO208.description: Physical features such as geology, landforms, biota, and waters of United States and Canadian national parks, forests, seashores and lakeshores. Emphasis on formation and distribution.

GEO211.name: Environmental Policy and Practice
GEO211.description: Systematic study of environmental policy and resource management practices in the United States and the broader global context, emphasizing geographical and other social sciences perspectives.

GEO214.name: Geography of Drugs
GEO214.description: Physical, ecological, and human geographies of drugs, drug crops, pharmaceuticals, alcohol, and their diffusions. Cultural geographies and geopolitical implications of drugs' consumption, trade, and regulation and prohibition.

GEO215.name: Sports Geography
GEO215.description: Geographical variables that influence the location, character, and spread of sports at the national and global scale. Human cultures and diffusion. Themes associated with the geography of sports. Origin and spread of collegiate, professional, international, and Olympic sports

GEO221.name: Introduction to Geographic Information
GEO221.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GEO221.description: Principles and methods of spatial data collection, handling, analysis, and display. Introduction to remote sensing, geographic information systems, and cartography.

GEO221L.name: Introduction to Geographic Information Laboratory
GEO221L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GEO221L.description: Basic skills for working with Geographic Information Systems, remotely sensed imagery, design of maps, geospatial tools and technologies for data analysis and problem-solving.

GEO235.name: Geography of Environment and Health
GEO235.description: Geographic patterns of global health and environmental inequalities; the built, physical and social environment; urban design; infectious and chronic diseases.

GEO259.name: Geography of Recreation and Tourism
GEO259.description: Cultural, physical, and biotic factors affecting the distribution of recreation and tourism resources and participation. U.S. and international examples and case studies.

GEO286.name: Undergraduate Research in Geography
GEO286.description: Supervised research on a topic or topics determined by the instructor. Applications of geographic tools and theory.

GEO302.name: Climates of the World
GEO302.description: Regional climates and underlying atmospheric circulation patterns. Climate classification, physical climatic processes, spatial and temporal aspects of climate, climate changes. Sources and use of climate data.

GEO303.name: Severe and Hazardous Weather
GEO303.description: Extratropical cyclones, freezing precipitation and ice storms, lake effect snowstorms, cold waves, blizzards, thunderstorms, tornadoes, downbursts, tropical cyclones, floods, drought, and heat waves.

GEO306.name: Environmental Geomorphology
GEO306.description: Relationships of running water, weathering, gravity, ice, waves, wind, and biota (including humans) to terrain and soils. Evolution of landscapes. Classical and modern interpretations.
GEO306.prerequisite: CSS 210 or GEO 206 or GEO 333 or GLG 201 or GLG 304 or ISP 203A

GEO314.name: Methods for Investigation of Urban Systems
GEO314.description: Models, approaches, and techniques for urban and regional problem analysis, research, program evaluation, and project management. Application of related computer software.

GEO324.name: Remote Sensing of the Environment
GEO324.description: Features and interpretation methods of remotely-sensed imagery, especially black-and-white and color infrared airphotos. Basic features of radar, thermal, and multispectral imagery. Interpretation for agriculture, archaeology, fisheries, forestry, geography, landscape architecture, planning, and wildlife management.

GEO325.name: Geographic Information Systems
GEO325.description: Technical and theoretical issues in the design, implementation, and use of geographic information systems for research and applications.

GEO326.name: Cartographic Design and Production
GEO326.description: Map design, layout, and usability. Typography and color theory. Techniques of map production, print and digital display.

GEO330.name: Geography of the United States and Canada
GEO330.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GEO330.description: Regional analysis. Evolution and status of environmental, demographic, economic, and sociocultural patterns and processes.

GEO333.name: Geography of Michigan and the Great Lakes Region
GEO333.description: Michigan's physical, historical, and economic geography. Interrelationships between the physical environment (rocks, landforms, soils, climate, vegetation, hydrology) and historical and contemporary land uses. Demographic and agricultural patterns. Human history and settlement patterns. Contemporary recreational opportunities.

GEO335.name: Geography of Latin America
GEO335.description: Physical and human geography of Latin America. Current development issues, especially people-environment interaction in urban and rural areas. Topics include migration, urbanization, and industrialization.

GEO336.name: Geography of Europe
GEO336.description: Major regions and nations, including their physical resources, peoples, political structures, and economies.

GEO337.name: Geography of Asia-Pacific
GEO337.description: Spatial patterns and processes of economic, urban, human and physical geography in eastern Asia, including China, Korea, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, the Indian subcontinent and other Asian countries. Contemporary regional development.

GEO338.name: Geography of Africa
GEO338.description: Physical and human geography of Africa. Current development issues, especially people-environment interaction in urban and rural areas. Topics include drought, agricultural patterns, hunger, rural development, migration, and urbanization.

GEO339.name: Geography of the Middle East and North Africa
GEO339.description: Physical and human geographies of the Middle East and North Africa. Historical and contemporary topics of ethno-nationalism, religion, state-building, and peace and conflict. Current issues of environment, development, urbanization, and global interactions.

GEO340.name: Geography of Eurasia
GEO340.description: Physical, ecological, and human geographies of the lands and peoples of the former Russian and Soviet empires and of neighboring regions.

GEO363.name: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for Geographers
GEO363.description: Quantitative techniques in the analysis and classification of spatial data.

GEO370.name: Introduction to Zoogeography
GEO370.description: Patterns of geographical distribution of animals and the ecological and historical processes leading to these patterns.

GEO372.name: Ecological Monitoring and Data Analysis
GEO372.description: Design of ecological monitoring systems and analysis of resulting ecological data sets. Monitoring system design, model specification and implementation, and computational considerations from both a design- and model-based perspective. Hands-on introduction to statistical software.
GEO372.prerequisite: ((MTH 124 or MTH 132) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (STT 201 or STT 224 or STT 231 or STT 421)

GEO401.name: Global Plant Geography
GEO401.description: Patterns of global plant distributions. Plant-atmosphere interactions, ecological processes, biogeographic patterns and predictive models of plant distributions.
GEO401.prerequisite: GEO 201 or FOR 101 or FOR 204 or PLB 218 or IBIO 355 or approval of department

GEO402.name: Agricultural Climatology
GEO402.description: Relationships between climate and agriculture in resource assessment, water budget analysis, meteorological hazards, pests, crop-yield modeling, and impacts of global climate change.
GEO402.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO403.name: Dynamic Meteorology (W)
GEO403.description: Principles of fluid dynamics and their application to the atmosphere.
GEO403.prerequisite: (MTH 234 and GEO 203) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
GEO403.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or master's students or doctoral students.

GEO405.name: Weather Analysis and Forecasting
GEO405.description: Dynamic and thermodynamic principles of atmospheric science applied to the development and evolution of extratropical cyclones. Laboratory sessions include analysis of current observations and satellite imagery.

GEO407.name: Regional Geomorphology of the United States
GEO407.description: Geomorphic characteristics of physiographic regions of the United States.

GEO408.name: Soil Geomorphology Field Study
GEO408.description: Common geographic relationships among soils, landforms, and vegetation in lower Michigan. Description, analysis, and genesis of soils and landscapes. Surficial processes.
GEO408.prerequisite: CSS 210 or GEO 306 or GLG 201 or GLG 412 or GEO 206
GEO408.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO409.name: Global Climate Change and Variability
GEO409.description: Analysis of climate change and variability at various time and space scales. Climate systems, paleoclimatology, global warming, climate models, and climate impact assessment.

GEO410.name: Geography of Food and Agriculture
GEO410.description: Spatial patterns of contemporary global agriculture and food systems. Human-environment geography of select agricultural practices and food systems. Effects of agricultural practices on natural and human resources.
GEO410.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO411.name: Stream Systems and Landforms
GEO411.description: Themes associated with stream systems. Evolution of drainage basins and channel hydrology. The nature of flowing water, stream discharge, and flooding. Controls of stream behavior. Channel patterns and landform development. Character of Michigan stream systems. Field project.
GEO411.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO412.name: Glacial Geology and the Record of Climate Change
GEO412.description: In-depth analysis of glacial geology and the record of climate change, with emphasis on North America and Europe. Field trip required.
GEO412.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO413.name: Urban Geography
GEO413.description: Theories and models of urban spatial form. Underlying structures and processes. Socio-spatial dimensions of modern urbanism. Differentiation and locational conflict in residential, commercial, and industrial space.
GEO413.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO414.name: Geography of Transportation
GEO414.description: Spatial principles of transportation. Theories of interaction, network structures, and location-allocation models. Role of transport and transport planning.

GEO415.name: Location Theory and Land Use Analysis
GEO415.description: Classical and neoclassical, static and dynamic models of industrial location and spatial organization. Land rent theory. Central place theory. Multi-locational organization. Growth transmission.
GEO415.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO418.name: The Ghetto
GEO418.description: Analysis of the ghetto including its spatial organization and structure. Distribution of racial and ethnic populations. Emphasis on U.S. cities.
GEO418.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO419.name: Applications of Geographic Information Systems to Natural Resources Management
GEO419.description: Application of geographic information systems, remote sensing, and global positioning systems to integrated planning and management for fish, wildlife, and related resources.

GEO424.name: Advanced Remote Sensing
GEO424.description: Interaction of solar radiation with the atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere. Introductory digital image processing. Earth-resources satellite sensors, data products, and applications. Radar and thermal remote sensing.

GEO425.name: Problems in Geographic Information Science (W)
GEO425.description: Advanced theoretical and technical issues in geographic information science utilizing a problems oriented approach. Development and implementation of geographic information science solutions and formal documentation of work.
GEO425.prerequisite: (GEO 325 or GEO 802) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

GEO426.name: Thematic Cartography
GEO426.description: Principles, theories, decision making, and techniques in thematic map production. Graphic and Geographic Information Systems applications. Print and digital display.
GEO426.prerequisite: GEO 221 and GEO 221L and GEO 326 or approval of department

GEO428.name: Digital Terrain Analysis
GEO428.description: Theoretical and technical issues of collection, management, analysis, and display of terrain data. Application of photogrammetry, geographic information systems, and cartography.

GEO429.name: Geoprocessing
GEO429.description: Applications of computer programming to address geographic information problems. Integration of digital spatial data, geographic information systems, spatial analysis, and expert systems.
GEO429.prerequisite: GEO 325 or GEO 802 or approval of department

GEO432.name: Environmental Ethics (W)
GEO432.description: Ethical dimensions of environmental and spatial issues and associated public policies
GEO432.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.
GEO432.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO435.name: Geography of Health and Disease
GEO435.description: Spatio-environmental concepts and techniques applied to health problems. Disease transmission cycles, community nutrition, and health-care planning.
GEO435.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO436.name: Spatial Analysis of Populations
GEO436.description: Concepts and methods to measure and evaluate geo-spatial and temporal trends in populations and their components, such as natality, mortality, migration, and characteristics at different geographic scales. Sources of spatial population data. Visualization and analysis of data in a geographical information system.
GEO436.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

GEO440.name: Critical Geopolitics
GEO440.description: Political geographies of origins and conduct of nation-states. Identity-place dynamics. Colonialism and imperialism. Geopolitics and geopolitical ideas. Resource and environmental politics. Resistance and terrorism.

GEO441.name: Cultural Geography
GEO441.description: Survey of the geographic study of world cultures, cultural ecologies, cultural landscapes, and cultural influences on societies’ patterns of spatial organization.

GEO442.name: Social Science Data Analytics Applications
GEO442.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GEO442.description: Application of computational tools for data collection and visualization to various topics in social science research.

GEO453.name: Metropolitan Environments: Urban Forms and Land Uses
GEO453.description: Land use change, the physical fabric of the city, and the growth of regional centers in the American urban landscape. Issues associated with urban developments, practices and patterns in the 20th century and the resulting metropolitan form and function. Extensive use of geographic information software in spatial analysis.

GEO459.name: Tourism in Regional Development
GEO459.description: The role of tourism in regional development. Examples from Michigan, the United States and other nations. Environmental considerations.

GEO460.name: Green Roofs and Walls
GEO460.description: Green roof and wall design and installation practices including plant species and substrates. Environmental impact, ecosystem services, integration with other environmental practices. Influence of economics, public policy, and industry organizations on the implementation of green roofs on a wide scale. Multidisciplinary nature of planning and implementation of successful green roof and wall projects.
GEO460.prerequisite: HRT 203 or FW 101 or GEO 206 or PDC 120 or EGR 100
GEO460.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

GEO478.name: Urban Transportation Planning
GEO478.description: Principles of decision-making in urban transportation planning. Demand and supply analysis, social and environmental impacts, implementation programs. Use of computer models.
GEO478.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Geography Major or in the Urban and Regional Planning Major or approval of school.

GEO480.name: Senior Seminar (W)
GEO480.description: History, philosophy, and methodology of the geographic discipline as it has evolved within academic and social contexts.
GEO480.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
GEO480.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Geography Major or in the Geography Minor.

GEO490.name: Independent Study
GEO490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GEO490.description: Supervised individual study in an area supplementary to regular courses.

GEO492.name: Geographic Research Problems
GEO492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GEO492.description: Supervised original research on selected aspects of geography.
GEO492.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores. Approval of department.

GEO495.name: Field Study
GEO495.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

GEO498.name: Internship in Geography
GEO498.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GEO498.description: Individual experience in geography in an approved organization.

GEO802.name: Geospatial Technology
GEO802.description: Comprehensive introduction to geotechnologies. Concepts and theories of remote sensing to include image interpretation and processing, Global Positioning Systems, spatial data structures, and geographic information systems.

GEO813.name: Seminar in Urban and Economic Geography
GEO813.description: Review of research on selected topics in urban and economic geography.

GEO816.name: The World System of Cities
GEO816.description: Modern global economic restructuring. Social, economic, and political impacts on world system of cities.

GEO817.name: China and Globalization
GEO817.description: Theoretical debates and empirical discussions on current social, economic, environmental, and spatial challenges facing contemporary urban China in an era of globalization. Comparative and thematic approach.

GEO819.name: Spatial Epidemiology and Medical Geography
GEO819.description: Concepts, techniques, and utilization of spatio-epidemiologic analyses for human health.
GEO819.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or in the Department of Geography or approval of department.

GEO826.name: Geocomputation
GEO826.description: Research on topics in cartography, geographic information systems, and remote sensing.

GEO827.name: Digital Image Processing and Analysis
GEO827.description: Use of computer to classify and enhance satellite images and to extract information from them. Combining images from different sources. Accuracy assessment of resulting information.

GEO837.name: Remote Sensing of the Biosphere
GEO837.description: Remote sensing for environmental and global change research. Advanced image interpretation and applications with emphasis on independent research projects.

GEO858.name: Gender, Justice and Environmental Change : Issues and Concepts
GEO858.description: Issues and concepts related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Key debates and theoretical approaches to addressing environmental issues from a gender and social justice perspective. Gender and environment issues and processes from a global perspective.

GEO859.name: Gender, Justice, and Environmental Change: Methods and Application
GEO859.description: Methods and case studies related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Methodological and fieldwork issues from a feminist perspective in international and intercultural contexts. Qualitative and quantitative methods for integrating social and environmental data.

GEO865.name: Advanced Quantitative Methods in Geography
GEO865.description: Statistical and mathematical approaches. Multiple regression, principal components and factor analysis, discriminant analysis. Related taxonomic methods.

GEO866.name: Spatial Data Analysis
GEO866.description: Theory and techniques for statistical analysis of point patterns, spatially continuous data, and data in spatial zones.

GEO869.name: Agent-Based Modeling
GEO869.description: Theoretical concepts related to simulating dynamic geographic phenomena in the intersection between human and natural systems. Innovative agent-based methodology applied to complex social-environmental systems. Hands-on experience of agent-based modeling, with special emphasis on modeling human decision-making and its impact on the natural environment.

GEO871.name: Seminar in Physical Geography
GEO871.description: Research on topics in physical geography.

GEO872.name: Seminar in Human Geography
GEO872.description: Research on topics in human geography.

GEO873.name: Seminar in Human-Environment Geography
GEO873.description: Research on topics in human-environment geography.

GEO874.name: Seminar in Geographic Information Science
GEO874.description: Geographic information science (GIS) applications to social and environmental problems. Theory and related issues.

GEO886.name: Research Design in Geography
GEO886.description: Research and writing in geography. Identification of geographic problems and their relative importance. Structuring and stating hypotheses. Data acquisition and tests for validity.

GEO890.name: Advanced Readings in Geography
GEO890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

GEO892.name: Advanced Research in Geography
GEO892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

GEO899.name: Master's Thesis Research
GEO899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

GEO986.name: Theories and Philosophies in Geography
GEO986.description: Historical development of the discipline within social and intellectual contexts. Philosophical approaches behind geographic research and theory.
GEO986.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Geography major.

GEO999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
GEO999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GEO999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Geography.
